destination.label: Miami
destination.title: A multicultural city, between fiction and reality

content.intro:
When it comes to Miami, everyone immediately thinks about its beaches and Art Deco architecture. But the city, one of the most populated in the state of Florida, also has many museums, green parks, and other surprising treasures that await you.

An image comes to mind when one mentions Miami: young people with sports-hardened physiques; girls, tanned and lovely, lying on a white sand beach. It's as if fashion models all flock here, looking for the omnipresent sun of Miami's subtropical climate. Though not completely misleading, this image is nonetheless simplistic. For Miami, the most cosmopolitan city in the United States, harbours many riches. Land of tourism, it has also been a haven for immigrants from Cuba and other Latin American countries since the 1960s. Spanish is Florida's second most widely spoken language.

In recent years, tourists have replaced retirees who have always come here for the heat in winter. Movement, vitality, and pleasure are what now characterise Miami, a fashionable and glamorous city. This revival is largely due to Miami Beach. While many show business stars have taken up residence here, they are not the city's main attraction, but rather, it's the Art Deco district, which you must visit. Facing the sea along Ocean Drive is a long line of pastel facades—all superbly renovated. If you have trouble going to sleep at night, go into hotel lobbies and admire the mirrors, chandeliers, and fireplaces. Because, at night, the flashing colour of neon signs makes for an unforgettable show.

Miami's cultural life is similarly vibrant. There are many private foundations and museums here, like the Wolfsonian and the Rubell Family Collection. In recent years, Miami has become an artistic hub due to Art Basel Miami, a major contemporary art fair, which, every December, brings together collectors from around the world. Many galleries have opened here, particularly in the Design District and the Wynwood Art District, both former warehouse districts. Painters and sculptors have workshops here. As usual, the artists were followed by the restaurants and bars, giving the district a new life.

Perhaps, after a few days, you will crave some quiet. If so, it is time to go to the Everglades, with its alligators, or to the Keys, a string of islands south of Miami. Go to legendary Key West, the one farthest away. There hovers the shadow of the writer Ernest Hemingway, who wrote some of his finest works while living there.

map.mapTitle: Our selection of must-see places in and around Miami

seoData.seoTitle: Travel Guide Miami  - Plan your trip to Miami with Air France Travel Guide
seoData.seoDescription: Stay in Miami: what to visit to Miami, where to stay, which restaurant to go? All information to prepare your holidays to Miami with Air France.

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Miami

content.title: Facing the sea in an old-school motel

introduction.small: The Shelley Hotel looks every bit like a 1960s beach motel, inviting you to relax wearing nothing but a bathing suit and flip flops.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Facing the sea in an old-school motel

paragraphs.text:
In Miami, this inshore establishment – Shelley Hotel being located about 200 metres from the beach – looks like the perfect combination of a typically American motel from the 1960s and a movie theatre from the same period. The beige facade, framed in grey and purple, is adorned with the large letters forming the name of the hotel. Inside, from the bedrooms to the bar, everything recalls the sixties, with Art Deco design and furniture. At the help desk, expect a warm welcome: start your stay with complimentary refreshing drinks and a beach bag, setting the tone for what is to come. There is one key word: chill. The staff will loan you beach towels and invite you to keep your flip flops on, whether you go for a swim or decide to sip on a cocktail behind the hotel, on the tropical terrace.

Shelley Hotel
844 Collins Avenue
Miami Beach, FL 33139

+1 305 531 3341

www.hotelshelley.com

Rooms: from 60 USD

content.title: Veza Sur, craft beer in a South American atmosphere

introduction.small: Far from Miami's classic pubs, Veza Sur is halfway between a beer hall and a hangout inspired by Latin American culture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Veza Sur, craft beer in a South American atmosphere

paragraphs.text:
A name appears in huge white letters on the black front of the warehouse and sets the tone: “Veza”, short for Spanish cerveza, meaning beer. In Miami, Veza is therefore specialised in crafted hopped drinks, with South American overtones. Beer lovers, take notice: in the heart of what looks like an industrial container of more than 3,000 sqm with high ceilings, you can choose from two dozen different selections, both local and international, not mentioning the famous Chopp, a popular Brasilian drink brewed on the spot. They can all be enjoyed – in moderation, obviously – while relaxing comfortably on a recycled bench seat or one of the colourful stools of the gigantic terrace. If you feel peckish, bring a snack from one of the multiple food trucks nearby. On the wall, wooden shelvings unveil a large book and board game selection, enticing you to stay and enjoy yourself a little while longer.

Veza Sur Brewing Co.
55 NW 25th Street
Miami, FL 33127

+1 786 362 6300

vezasur.com

Carte : bière à partir de 4 USD

content.title: At Fooq's, just like home!

introduction.small: David Foulquier, world renowned French-Iranian restaurant owner, arranged a true culture shock at Fooq's. Try it, without delay!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: At Fooq's, just like home!

paragraphs.text:
Located in the new arts and entertainment district of Miami's city centre, Fooq's offers food of international influences in an urban and comfortable setting. From the get-go, the restaurant feels welcoming with a white wooden bench covered in pillows and a coffee table stacked with cookbooks. As for the main dining area, it is bright and airy.
There, dishes of Italian, French, Iranian and even Asian influences are being revisited and enhanced in your plate with locally-farmed produce.
You will have a choice of small crusty Brussels sprouts, octopus in citrus fruits and braised lamb. Larger servings count sliced lamb platters, fish in tarragon and smoked chicken with raisins. As for desserts, the traditional butter cake will dazzle you with simplicity, while the dark chocolate cream in olive oil will take you to heaven!

Fooq's
1035 N Miami Avenue
Miami, FL 33136

+1 786-536-2749

www.fooqsmiami.com

Menu: from 27 USD

content.title: Alter, among Wynwood's very best

introduction.small: In this trendy Miami neighbourhood at the forefront of street art movements, Alter stands out with unlabelled sophisticated cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Alter, among Wynwood's very best

paragraphs.text:
As soon as it opened, the restaurant was a smash hit among food critics. With refined and creative cuisine using unlikely combinations and remarkable wine pairing, as well as top-notch service, Alter positioned as a must-go-to in the hip Wynwood neighbourhood. Chef Brad Kilgore developed a menu that he wants “unlabelled”, changing with the seasons and using Florida-based products, if not downright from restaurant's own vegetable garden, in which herbs and produce are being farmed. Choose the regional oyster mushrooms, with soy sauce icing and yuba chips, or the grilled duck breast with fir cones in sake. While waiting for your table, head over to the bar and enjoy, in moderation of course, a shandy (beer cocktail) or one of the various creations offered by the mixologists. From pre-dinner drinks to dessert, all flavours are bound to dazzle you!

Alter
223 NW 23rd Street
Miami, FL 33127

+1 305 573 59 96

www.altermiami.com ﻿

Tasting menu: from 75 USD

content.title: Gold Coast Railroad Museum, a train affair

introduction.small: Gold Coast Railroad Museum, family museum and paradise for historic railway wagon lovers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gold Coast Railroad Museum, a train affair

paragraphs.text:
First railway museum in the State of Florida and one of the most beautiful in the United States, the Gold Coast Railroad Museum will absolutely amaze young and old alike. During your guided visit, you will discover over 40 antique yet restored railway wagons like the “Ferdinand Magellan”, the armoured wagon used by presidents Roosevelt, Truman and Eisenhower, classified today as a “National Historic Monument”.
Get on board, explore them from end to end, visit steam and diesel locomotives and their drivers' cabins. If you come on the weekend, you will have a chance to go for a train ride. Learn all there is to know about the history of these railway vehicles and the hectic past of the museum, and attend numerous events and exhibits organized throughout the year.

Gold Coast Railroad Museum
12450 SW 152nd Street
Miami, FL 33177-1402

+1 305 253 0063

www.gcrm.org

content.title: The refreshing and gourmet break of Frieze Ice Cream Factory

introduction.small: Considered as the best ice cream maker in South Beach, Frieze Ice Cream Factory sets the standard.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The refreshing and gourmet break of Frieze Ice Cream Factory

paragraphs.text:
Since 1987, Frieze Ice Cream Factory tantalizes taste buds with their homemade ice cream. Tubs are filled with new ice creams handcrafted with love each day with surprising and innovative flavours. All are made from only natural ingredients imported from around the world, with no artificial colours, preservatives or additives. Enter this small shop and choose your flavour from among a large selection. Dare to test the cider, red wine or champagne flavour for rather fruity-alcoholic tastes or mix a scoop of key lime pie with another of pumpkin. You will also love the sorbet – coconut or cinnamon – or the Bumpy Trail, a true delight with chocolate, almonds and pieces of marshmallow. Named the "Best Ice Cream Shop" by the New York Times in 2012, Frieze Ice Cream Factory continues to attract more and more locals and tourists alike. All you have to do is form your own opinion on the matter.

Frieze Ice Cream Factory
1626 Michigan Avenue
Miami Beach, FL 33139

+1 305 538 0207

www.thefrieze.com

content.title: W South Beach, luxury in Miami's centre

introduction.small: During your Miami holiday, book at W South Beach for a royal stay.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: W South Beach, luxury in Miami's centre

paragraphs.text:
A four-star hotel in Miami, W South Beach welcomes you to a resort with iconic decor. Ideally located for shopping, taking a stroll, sightseeing or spending an afternoon sunbathing on the fine sand of Miami Beach, you will be close to Ocean Drive, the famous Art Deco neighbourhood, and Everglades National Park. Just steps away from the beach, indulge in various water activities such as scuba diving, jet skiing, boating or fishing.
If you prefer the tranquillity of your hotel, two swimming pools are at your disposal. As for your bright and spacious room, enjoy splendid views of the versatile ocean colours from an immense glass balcony overlooking palm-tree lined Collins Avenue. Spa, tennis court and fitness centre are also available for a stimulating and relaxing stay.

W South Beach
2201 Collins Avenue
Miami Beach, FL 33139

+1 305 938 3000

www.wsouthbeach.com

Rooms: from 355 USD

content.title: Ghee Indian Kitchen, flavours from elsewhere

introduction.small: Ghee Indian Kitchen offers a modern approach that respects the flavours of traditional Indian cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ghee Indian Kitchen, flavours from elsewhere

paragraphs.text:
Niven Patel, the talented chef at Ghee Indian Kitchen is very clear: he wants his guests to feel at home when they walk in the doorway of his restaurant where appetising aromas waft in from the kitchen. The chef is uncompromising on the quality of the products. Some come straight from the restaurant's own farm, while others are carefully selected from local fishermen and other farmers. The result is traditional Indian gastronomy raised to its highest level.

Whether you are dining at the Dadeland or Design District branch, the menu changes daily and offers you subtly reinterpreted authentic dishes: smoked lamb collar and chickpeas, duck samosa confit with cranberry chutney and green mango, Key West shrimp with corn and lemon, or the marinated fish of the day in coco-curry sauce… Our advice? Wait no longer and give it a try!

Ghee Indian Kitchen (Downtown Dadeland)
8965 SW 72nd Place
Miami, FL 33156

Ghee Indian Kitchen (Design District)
3620 NE 2nd Avenue
Miami FL 33137

+1 305 968 1850 (Dadeland location)
+1 786 636 6122 (District Design location)

www.gheemiami.com

Menu: around 27 USD

articles.topic: plunge beach, for the sake of the sea

content.title: CHARM - WATER ACTIVITIES

introduction.small: A short walk from Biscayne Bay, Plunge Beach Hotel offers a moment of calm to travellers from all over the world. Welcome!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: CHARM - WATER ACTIVITIES

paragraphs.text:
It is right by the sea that you can explore the spaces and rooms of Plunge Beach, a jewel of discretion in the heart of Miami. With public areas resembling an industrial loft, the charming establishment is idyllically located and welcomes travellers in search of a break, and who want to enjoy this Floridian city.

Access to a fitness centre, valet parking, breathtaking views, sports activities, sun loungers, parasols for hotel guests and bicycles loaned by the hotel… all this and more will be available if you choose Plunge Beach Hotel.

Plunge Beach
4660 El Mar Dr. Lauderdale by the Sea
Miami, FL 33308

+1 754 200 3346

www.plungebeachhotel.com

Rooms: from 149 USD

content.title: Shelley's, the freshness of the sea

introduction.small: In a historic building in South Miami we have found a new gourmet address. Shelley's puts seafood in the limelight. Enjoy your meal!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Shelley's, the freshness of the sea

paragraphs.text:
Since November 2017, this new establishment has offered its customers the experience of high-calibre cuisine in a laidback atmosphere. Shelley's offers a variety of seafood with all ingredients scrupulously chosen for freshness and quality. You will appreciate the team's know-how in this exceptional restaurant: not only are they very experienced, but also devoted.

Explore all the facets and flavours of a menu that varies daily - for the delight of loyal customers. On the menu, the famous lobster roll, crab cakes in hollandaise sauce, croquetes stuffed with 102-hour ham, gouda cheese and crab, or a revisited Caesar salad with kale. Have you booked your table yet?

Shelley's
5845 Sunset Dr.
South Miami, FL 33143

Tel: +1 786 534 7830

www.shelleysmiami.com

Menu: around 30 USD

content.title: Lowe Art Museum, art from all walks of life

introduction.small: Lowe Art Museum, University of Miami's art museum, undoubtedly holds one of South Florida's largest collections with around 17,500 objects.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lowe Art Museum, art from all walks of life

paragraphs.text:
Founded in 1950, Lowe Art Museum is home to an enormous and varied collection ranging from the Greek Antiquity to 20th century works through the American art of the first Indians.
Works come from all continents. In the section dedicated to the West, discover several masterpieces from Europe's Renaissance and Baroque periods; then head to America with its 2,000 artistic productions from the 19th and 20th century. In the Asia department, admire the many ceramics, paintings and sculptures, whether Chinese, Korean or Japanese, before taking a long detour through the Africa and Oceania area.
On the modern art side, you will not be disappointed with works from artists such as Roy Lichtenstein, Andy Warhol, Jackson Pollock and Joan Miró as well as older works that have already risen to the ranks of the “great classics”, including those of Gauguin and Monet…

Lowe Art Museum
1301 Stanford Drive
Coral Gables, FL 33124

+1 305 284 3535

https://www.lowe.miami.edu/

content.title: Three for a tasting right in the kitchen

introduction.small: A true beacon of Florida cuisine, Three has chosen to set up shop in the heart of Wynwood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Three for a tasting right in the kitchen

paragraphs.text:
Head for the famous Wynwood district, an open-air museum where street artists express themselves on the walls. Chef Miguel Massens of Three and his team invite you to share a unique experience where customers have the opportunity to converse and interact with them at the chef's counter, discovering some of the techniques and the process of creating dishes, while enjoying the refined and welcoming service.

A true celebration of Florida's gastronomy, Three offers a gourmet menu: cachapas (Venezuelan corn tortillas) filled with corn, foie gras and caramelised onions, barbecued green asparagus, swordfish in chimichurri sauce that is typical of the region... With such quality, it's three cheers for Three!

Three
50 NW 24th Street
Miami, FL 33127

+1 305 748 4540

www.threewynwood.com

Menu: around 50 USD

content.title: Stubborn Seed, the refinement of gastronomy

introduction.small: On Washington Avenue, the Stubborn Seed restaurant is a hit with Florida foodies. Discover an exceptional establishment.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Stubborn Seed, the refinement of gastronomy

paragraphs.text:
In the kitchen is Jeremy Ford, winner of the 13th American season of Top Chef! With Stubborn Seed, this young thirty-something has opened his first restaurant, where contemporary design mixes with Art Deco style, warmed by the brown and ochre tones of the furniture. The dishes prepared with undeniable perfection delight the eyes and meet your expectations: on the menu, homemade pasta stuffed with asparagus and aged parmesan, organic chicken with truffle butter and gnocchi, lobster in green curry served with caramelised cauliflower... Or perhaps you will be tempted by the five-course menu? Dare to indulge, because at Stubborn Seed it is worth it!

The marriage of flavours is perfectly realised in all the dishes that are proposed to you and each bite will lead you to the seventh heaven of gastronomy.

Stubborn Seed
101 Washington Avenue
Miami Beach, FL 33139

+1 786 322 5211

www.stubbornseed.com

Menu: from 55 USD

content.title: SLS Brickell, for an irresistible retreat

introduction.small: From the heights of the hotel, you can enjoy an unobstructed view of Miami's city centre. Discover an amazing establishment with carefully conceived spaces.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: SLS Brickell, for an irresistible retreat

paragraphs.text:
From one room to another, you can explore the various aspects of this building, dreamed up by hotel owner Sam Nazarian and conceived by the famous designer Philippe Starck. A stunning, bright and sophisticated decor is everywhere to be seen, from the floor-to-ceiling windows of the lavish rooms to the upscale amenities of the hotel's community areas.

On the agenda for your stay are the inspired culinary creations of the famous chefs, José Andrés and Michael Schwartz, a huge open-air swimming pool offering incredible views of the horizon, VIP access to Delano Miami Beach, steam baths at Ciel Spa with the most modern facilities, as well as a fitness centre and free yoga classes.

There, the expression “the customer is king” is taken seriously and the hotel exudes serenity and tranquillity. Look no further, paradise is at hand.

SLS Brickell
1300 South Miami Avenue
Miami, FL 33130

+1 305 239 1300

www.slshotels.com/brickell/

Rooms: from 209 USD

content.title: Wynwood, the enchanting neighbourhood of urban art

introduction.small: North of Downtown Miami, the city's business district, Wynwood is home to treasures well known to the initiated, but perhaps unknown to many.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Wynwood, the enchanting neighbourhood of urban art

paragraphs.text:
Wynwood is home to some of the world's finest works of urban art. In 2009, about 20 artists were invited to create art on Wynwood Walls. Since then, the neighbourhood has been covered with the invigorating colours of graffiti artists. The frescoes roll by but are not alike. You will recognize the signature of the artist baptized Evoca 1, driven by his desire to awaken consciences to the painful conditions of homeless men. More lightly, KashinK paints colourful portraits of four-eyed characters, while Steep draws his mystical creatures in the heart of Amazonian biodiversity.

A real open-air museum, come and discover the atypical walls of Wynwood, chosen by the best painters on the streets to express a creativity that is still too little known. Opt for the guided Art Walk Tour to not miss a thing!

Wynwood
NW 2nd Avenue
Miami, FL 33127

+1 305 814 9290

wynwoodmiami.com

content.title: Byblos Miami: the Mediterranean on the east coast of Florida

introduction.small: At Byblos Miami, taste the flavours of the Oriental Mediterranean, subtly mixed with traditional and local products.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Byblos Miami: the Mediterranean on the east coast of Florida

paragraphs.text:
In a setting where conviviality is king, the Byblos invites you to enjoy mantis, Turkish raviolis, stuffed here with smoked eggplant and yoghurt sauce, or fried chicken Middle-East style, with tahini and zaatar, a Lebanese mix of spices. Make yourself comfortable in the blue and yellow seating elegantly awaiting you in this modern and southern space-the chef will take care of the rest.

In the evening, plunge into the hotel's lounge to extend the culinary experience in a seductive atmosphere. Night falls on Miami. Try the Gulab, the house cocktail made from vodka, pomegranate syrup, fresh lemon and rose essence. Alluring, is it not?

Byblos
1545 Collins Avenue
Miami Beach, FL 33139

+1 (305) 508 5041

www.byblosmiami.com/

Menu: around 45 USD

content.title: Welcome to the Adrienne Arsht Center for the Performing Arts

introduction.small: After ten years of construction, the Adrienne Arsht Center for the Performing Arts has opened in Miami-Dade County. Love the arts, follow the guide!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Welcome to the Adrienne Arsht Center for the Performing Arts

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of one of the largest urban centres in the world, the Adrienne Arsht Center for the Performing Arts borders Biscayne Bay. Designed by architect César Pelli, the establishment multiplies the spaces it dedicates to artistic expression: the Ziff Ballet Opera House, the John S. and James L. Knight concert hall or the Parker and Vann Thomson Plaza for the Arts.
Guarantor of a rich and innovative programming, the centre reflects the artistic diversity of South Florida in its roughly 500 events each year: Broadway in Miami, Jazz Roots, The Masterworks Season. Living legends and local artists succeed each other and hundreds of spectators come to admire their vibrant and creative performances. A cultural and artistic mosaic full of life that you must not miss for anything in the world.

Adrienne Arsht Center for the Performing Arts
1300 Biscayne Boulevard
Miami, FL 33132

+1 305 949 6722

www.arshtcenter.org

content.title: An Ancient Spanish Monastery rebuilt in Miami

introduction.small: The monastery of St. Bernard of Clairvaux was built in the 12th century in Spain, but it is in Miami that the cloister, the chapter house and the refectory can now be visited.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: An Ancient Spanish Monastery rebuilt in Miami

paragraphs.text:
Named in honour of Bernard of Clairvaux in 1174, the monastery was home to Cistercian monks for nearly 700 years. In the 1830s, the social revolution in Spain brought with it the cloisters of the building: they were sold, then converted into an attic and a stable. In 1925, the American businessman William Randolph Hearst acquired the monastery, dismounted it stone by stone, then repatriated it to California, distributed in more than 10,000 cases. It was not until the 1950s that the structure was partially rebuilt on American soil, earning it the title of “the greatest puzzle in history” by Time magazine.

Today, some religious services are being performed both in English and Spanish. It is also an ideal setting for many newlyweds who have their photographs taken in the cloister and gardens of the monastery.

The Ancient Spanish Monastery
16711 West Dixie Highway
33160 North Miami Beach

+1 305 945 1461

www.spanishmonastery.com

content.title: News Cafe, around the clock

introduction.small: An iconic Miami Beach address, News Cafe is open day and night.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: News Cafe, around the clock

paragraphs.text:
When it opened in South Beach in 1988, News Cafe was a novelty: a quiet place to have coffee and read the international press. Almost 30 years later, the 'News' is still there. Initially inspired by European cafes, it has since become a typical American restaurant, and a must on the South Beach scene. Open every day around the clock, it changes throughout the day. In the morning when Ocean Drive is still groggy from going out all night, that's the place to go - on the patio for coffee, pancakes and a newspaper. The tables fill up gradually. Late risers wake up with a detox salad and fresh fruit juice, unless they opt for a panini with prosciutto ham, spinach and pesto, a turkey burger, grilled chicken pasta with tomato sauce, garlic and basil, or pizza with whatever you want on it. It goes on like this until evening. After nightfall, it turns into the 'before' and 'after' hang-out spot.

800 Ocean Drive
Miami Beach, FL 33139

+1 305 538 6397

www.newscafe.com

Menu: around 20 USD

content.title: Play golf in Florida

introduction.small: There are countless golf courses in Florida. All are beautiful and some are legendary.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Play golf in Florida

paragraphs.text:
With its temperate climate in summer and winter, Florida is the home of golf.

There are numerous courses, and, near Miami, one of the most beautiful is the Doral Resort, which has five courses. All the great champions have played on the spectacular and arduous blue course. Its bunkers, deep rough, and water hazards require power and finesse on the part of the players. The 18th hole, especially, is among the most challenging in the world. You may prefer, north of Miami Beach, Turnberry Isle Golf Club, designed by Robert Trent Jones, or the Biltmore Golf Course, designed in 1925 by a Scottish architect, located right next to the legendary Biltmore Hotel in Coral Gables.

Rates are substantially higher in the winter, which is the best season. In summer, there are often afternoon storms, so choose your tee-off time carefully.

Doral Golf Course
4400 NW 87th Avenue
Miami, FL 33178

+1 305 592 2000

https://www.trumpgolfdoral.com/Golf

content.title: Nobu: one of the great names in contemporary gastronomy

introduction.small: Sober decor, refined cuisine, and high prices—these are the three characteristics of the restaurant that has elevated Asian fusion to new heights.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Nobu: one of the great names in contemporary gastronomy

paragraphs.text:
If you are familiar with the gastronomy of the great Nobu Matsuhisa, one of the inventors and champions of Asian fusion, you will not be surprised by the fare on offer here. This is one of the strongholds of his empire. The decor of the restaurant, which is in the hotel Eden Roc in Miami Beach, is chic without ostentation — almost too minimalist, according to its detractors. Beige, brown, white, blue, everything is done to focus the customer's attention onto the plate.

At Nobu, you eat Japanese cuisine that has been revisited and modernized. The sushi is excellent, the maki very original, the sashimi delicious. Kobe beef is also on the menu. In short, everything is top quality and the service is impeccable.

You may be placed at seats right in front of the kitchen, where the dishes are prepared. The dexterous demonstration of technique is fascinating. The restaurant is not open for lunch but stays open late at night.

Nobu
4525 Collins Avenue
Miami Beach, FL 33140

+1 305 695 3232

www.noburestaurants.com/miami

Menu: from 65 USD

content.title: Prime 112: the ‘it-spot' in Miami

introduction.small: Chic and expensive, this is where the celebrities flock.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Prime 112: the ‘it-spot' in Miami

paragraphs.text:
It is very good, and very expensive, and very fashionable, so, of course, it is very noisy. Opened in 2004 in the historic Brown Hotel by Myles Chefetz, the Prime 112 has many strengths: a dream location, almost at the tip of South Beach; and a modern and elegant room with brick walls, black tables, and intimate lighting. The steakhouse soon became the favorite rendezvous spot for celebrities and models.

The food is delicious giant T-bone steaks, whole lobsters stuffed with crab and scallops and basted in cognac butter, or Kobe beef hot dogs, all accompanied by sauces and generous portions of vegetables. For lunch you can choose from soups, a staggering number of salads and sandwiches, plus the full range of grilled meats.

But night's the time to come and see and be seen. Even if you have booked an obligation you may be in for a long wait. No doubt, this is the price of success…

Prime 112
112 Ocean Drive
Miami Beach, FL 33139

+1 305 532 8112

www.mylesrestaurantgroup.com

Menu: from 100 USD

content.title: The Keys: in the footsteps of giants

introduction.small: Key Largo or Key West? Bogart and Bacall or Hemingway and Tennessee Williams? To each his own...

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Keys: in the footsteps of giants

paragraphs.text:
At the far end of Florida is a string of coral islands called the Keys. Between Key Largo, the nearest, and Key West, the furthest, there are nearly 200 kilometres and 40 bridges to traverse, a trip that makes you feel like you are playing leapfrog.

Key Largo is far from the most beautiful, but you could make a stop there in memory of the eponymous film, starring Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall. The star of the islands is the legendary Key West, where Ernest Hemingway and Tennessee Williams wrote some of their works. Although the island is a bit overrun by tourists in high season, it has great charm with its small, perfectly maintained wooden houses.

Visit the house where Hemingway lived from 1931 to 1940. In his office, a little separate from the rest of the house because the novelist needed quiet to write, his favourite books and some hunting trophies are carefully preserved. Many cats have invaded the garden. Their peculiarity is that they have six claws on their paws…

Hemingway Home & Museum
907 Whitehead St
Key West, FL 33040

+1 305 294 1136

www.hemingwayhome.com

content.title: Biltmore Hotel: the celebrity rendezvous

introduction.small: With its impressive lobby, 273 rooms, and famous restaurants, this hotel is worth the trip. Even if you don't stay here, drop by for a drink.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Biltmore Hotel: the celebrity rendezvous

paragraphs.text:
This hotel is a National Historic Landmark, not just because it was built in 1926 by George Merrick, who, in 1920, bought the 4,000 hectares of land that became Coral Gables. Nor just because of its Moorish architecture and pink facade. No, it's because throughout its history, except, perhaps, when it was converted into a hospital, the Biltmore has been frequented by famous people.

Johnny Weissmuller, the swimmer and actor who made the best Tarzan, was a lifeguard here. Al Capone, the famous gangster, stayed here.

Today, however, people come for its timeless charm and the 273 rooms furnished in typical American style. They also come for its restaurants: the Palme d'Or reinterprets classical French cuisine, while Fontana, around the courtyard fountain, offers Italian dishes. On Sunday morning, a Champagne brunch is served to residents, yes, but also to visitors.

Biltmore Hotel
1200 Anastasia Avenue
Coral Gables, FL 33134

+1 305 311 6903

www.biltmorehotel.com

Rooms: from 287 USD

content.title: Vizcaya Museum: the time of the Renaissance

introduction.small: Once the house of a recluse, the Vizcaya is one of Miami's most popular tourist spots. This mansion contains treasures.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Vizcaya Museum: the time of the Renaissance

paragraphs.text:
This is probably one of the most amazing places in the Miami area. Visit the Vizcaya villa, an Italian Renaissance-style mansion that overlooks Biscayne Bay, and you will believe yourself four centuries back in time. It was actually built between 1914 and 1916.

At the time, about a thousand workers made the dream of a lonely old man fascinated by the Renaissance come true. With his fortune, James Deering, heir to a company manufacturing farm equipment, built this palace of three floors decorated with furniture, tapestries, carpets, sculptures, and other works of art purchased in European antiques stores.

The gardens are in the image of the building: fountains, statues, and small bridges give them the look of an Italian park. Visit the lounges, the music room with its painted walls, the dining room, the patio with its limestone flooring inlaid with coral, and the kitchen with its display of Quimper pottery… Everything is fascinating.

Vizcaya Museum
3251 S Miami Avenue
Miami, FL 33129

+1 305 250 9133

www.vizcaya.org

content.title: Faena Hotel Miami Beach: fashion or nothing at all

introduction.small: Everyone's talking about this new hotel. Beautifully decorated, a little bling-bling, but that's what makes it so Miami.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Faena Hotel Miami Beach: fashion or nothing at all

paragraphs.text:
It is the showstopper of the Faena District in North Miami Beach between 32nd and 36th Street. While apartment buildings, shops, and a cultural centre have yet to be completed, the hotel opened in November 2015 on the site of the former Saxony, built in 1947. Its 58 rooms and 111 suites extend over 14 floors. The rooms are big (the smallest is 37 square meters) and decorated by Catherine Martin, the Oscar-winning movie costume designer.

Her inspiration was the 1950s: the dominant colours are red and turquoise, from the carpets on the floors to the vintage furniture, with a few small touches of gold. At Los Fuegos restaurant, Argentine chef Francis Mallmann serves asados, meat grilled on outdoor barbecues.

For Asian cuisine, go to Pao restaurant, helmed by Chef Paul Qui. And because the Faena is determined to gain notice in a town where nothing surprises, a work by Damien Hirst has been installed: a golden mammoth skeleton encased in a glass cage.

Faena Hotel Miami Beach
3201 Collins Avenue
Miami Beach, FL 33140

+1 305 534 8800

www.faena.com

Rooms: from 446 USD

content.title: Miami Beach and its many activities

introduction.small: Kilometres of sand and turquoise waters—a dream setting for sunbathing, swimming, and diving.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Miami Beach and its many activities

paragraphs.text:
A beautiful beach stretches for kilometres north and south of Miami Beach. And what a setting! Observation posts and rescue lifeguards evoke the 1950s. Hotel parasols and deck chairs between Collins Avenue and Ocean Drive are installed in tight rows on the sand.

On public beaches, it is also possible to rent a deck chair by the hour or by the day. If you don't feel like lazing in the sun or swimming, walk along the palm-lined promenade and admire the turquoise sea on one side, and the colourful facades of the buildings on the other. Here, tanned young men with chiselled bodies jog and play beach volleyball. Photographers snap photos of pretty girls posing for European magazines.

This is how life flows in Miami Beach. And though the beach is artificial—due to erosion it must be replenished with sand every year—it is beautiful under the almost permanent sunshine.

Miami Beach

content.title: Biscayne National Park: explore the sea-bed

introduction.small: This national park refuge is a respite from the bustle of Miami.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Biscayne National Park: explore the sea-bed

paragraphs.text:
You can walk along the seashore at Convoy Point. But the best thing to do is to take a boat tour. Allow about three hours from the Dante Fascell Visitor Center. Through the glass-bottomed boat, you will discover the underwater flora and fauna.

You will see coral, as well as a thousand species of fish, lobsters, and crabs. It is an unforgettable experience that will make you feel like you are swimming in the turquoise sea.

Out of the water, you can witness a ballet of herons, cormorants, and pelicans spending their day diving for their lunch. Off in the distance are the forested Florida Keys. The landscape is magical, but do not forget that many ships have run aground on these coral reefs…

Dante Fascell Visitor Center
9700 SW 328th St
Homestead, FL 33033

+1 305 230 1144

content.title: Mandolin Aegean Bistro: under the Greek sun

introduction.small: Close your eyes and you're no longer in Miami, but on the Mediterranean coast.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mandolin Aegean Bistro: under the Greek sun

paragraphs.text:
A Greek island under the Miami sun: that's the feeling one has in this charming taverna housed in a lovely house from the 1940s.

From the blue doorway, tavern chairs with blue legs, wooden tables, a garden where they grow organic tomatoes and herbs… everything here has a Mediterranean feel to it. Like the food: grilled fish and vegetables presented in a simple, almost rustic way, just as they are in a small village in Greece or Turkey, where family and friends gather on Sunday to share the meal.

Ahmet Erkaya and his wife Anastasia love to please their customers by offering dishes from their home countries: tzatziki, hummus, grilled octopus, calamari, and meatballs. The wines all come from local independent producers.

Mandolin Aegean Bistro
4312 NE 2nd Avenue
Miami, FL 33137

+1 305 749 9140

www.mandolinmiami.com

Menu: from 40 USD

content.title: Sugarcane: for all tastes

introduction.small: It is difficult to make a choice here because the restaurant offers dozens of dishes in a relaxed and lively atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sugarcane: for all tastes

paragraphs.text:
This restaurant serves throughout the day. And it is always full because of its many loyal customers. Sit in the hall, on the red banquette or on one of the mismatched chairs. Unless, of course, you prefer the much quieter patio.

The atmosphere in this place, which attracts a young clientele, is often very animated. No doubt you will have a hard time choosing among all the dishes on the menu. There is something for everyone, including sushi, sashimi, grilled meats, and oysters, plus all the tapas: chicken, duck, and scallops, to name only a few…

If you are really hungry, order the whole roast chicken. Brunch is served on Saturdays and Sundays. There are also very original cocktails, especially those based on rum or prosecco, and all the sodas are made in house.

Sugarcane
132 N Miami Ave
Miami, FL 33127

+1 786 369 0353

www.sugarcanerawbargrill.com

Menu: from 32 USD

content.title: Coconut Grove: bohemian Miami

introduction.small: An artistic village far from the bustle of downtown.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Coconut Grove: bohemian Miami

paragraphs.text:
Coconut Grove, south of Miami, is like a village. In the 19th century, it was the neighbourhood of immigrants from the Bahamas, and then, in the 1960s, a hippy enclave. Today, a slightly bohemian but affluent population lives here.

You will love walking along the shady streets, past vast lawns and beautiful homes with gardens. There are fashionable boutiques, small restaurants with patios, bars, and art galleries everywhere. Many stores are in Coco Walk, a three-storey shopping centre built in Spanish style.

For sightseers, there is the Charlotte Jane Memorial Park Cemetery where they say Michael Jackson was inspired for to write his song Thriller. And the Barnacle Historic State Park is worth a visit: it features beautiful trees surrounding a magnificent late-19th century house built by a naval architect and nature-lover. Both the house and the architect's studio are open to the public.

Barnacle Historic State Park
3485 Main Highway
Miami, FL 33133

+1 305 442 6866

www.floridastateparks.org

content.title: The Angler's Hotel: a quiet oasis

introduction.small: A lovely hotel with very quiet rooms, the Angler's Hotel attracts a loyal clientele.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Angler's Hotel: a quiet oasis

paragraphs.text:
This hotel is not located on Collins Avenue, like so many others, so it therefore has no direct view of the beach.

Yet, to its many loyal customers, it has plenty of other assets. First, it only has 85 rooms, making it a hotel of human scale, almost intimate. Its rooms and suites, some on two floors, are very spacious, making a stay of average length very pleasant. They are nicely decorated, with tasteful furniture, bamboo floors, and marble bathrooms. Even more appealing is this boutique hotel's staff. The reception is first-rate, and the service very efficient.

Upon your arrival you will be greeted with kindness and competence. Every evening, a wine tasting is held. In summary, and given the price, this hotel offers outstanding benefits.

The Angler's Hotel
660 Washington Avenue
Miami Beach, FL 33139

+1 305 534 9600

www.anglershotelmiami.com

Rooms: from 203 USD

content.title: Design District: artists and antique dealers

introduction.small: Once a no man's land, this Miami neighbourhood has become a design mecca, and one of the most sought-after areas in the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Design District: artists and antique dealers

paragraphs.text:
North of downtown Miami, this area was almost deserted in the 1980s and 1990s. Today it has the largest concentration of art galleries and design shops. Besides contemporary art, antiques have also settled in this area, as well as artists, attracted by low rents.

There are also many bars and restaurants. Walk a little further north toward Wynwood, where the warehouses of yesterday have given way to galleries and artists' studios. Private museums have also emerged.

The most renowned is the Margulies Collection At The Warehouse on 27th Street (which has been around for more than 15 years), and the Rubell Family Collection, two streets away. Admire the many painted frescoes on the facades. It seems that the whole area has now become a museum…

Margulies Collection At The Warehouse
591 NW 27th St
Miami, FL 33127

+1 305 576 1051

www.margulieswarehouse.com

content.title: The Rubell family and contemporary art

introduction.small: In a beautiful building, the Rubells have amassed a beautiful collection of art. And they generously exhibit it.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Rubell family and contemporary art

paragraphs.text:
What would American museums be without patrons? Because of their generosity, rooms are filled with masterpieces. This is one of the largest private collections of contemporary art, open to the public since 1993, and compiled by Donald and Mera Rubell, a wealthy couple from New York.

What do they like? The works of artists from the 1960s up to today: Jeff Koons, Keith Haring, Paul McCarthy, Jean-Michel Basquiat. The first work they bought was a 1964 Robert Motherwell. Their choices are often daring, which may not appeal to all visitors.

All these works are exhibited over several storeys in a huge industrial space in the Wynwood Art District. The collection continues to evolve, as Rubell continues to buy, especially the works of young artists. Some of the exhibitions here are then presented in other museums. The openings are popular with Miami's beautiful people.

Rubell Family Collection
95 NW 29th St
Miami, FL 33127

+1 305 573 6090

www.rfc.museum

content.title: Make your credit card sizzle…

introduction.small: Miami Beach is not just about beaches. There's plenty of great shopping, too.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Make your credit card sizzle…

paragraphs.text:
Lincoln Road is a wide pedestrian street, especially between Washington Avenue and Alton Road, where all the trendy shops are, both big names and smaller boutiques. If the Art Deco facades have been restored here as well, it's not only to admire them that everyone comes to Lincoln Road. They come to buy clothes, shoes, books, cosmetics…

Besides the inevitable international brands, you can also visit Victoria's Secret underwear. With your arms full of packages, take a break on one of the patios. For those with luxury tastes, have a look at Webster, the chic Collins Avenue boutique founded by Frenchwoman Laure Heriard-Dubreuil.

For bargains, go much further to Sawgrass Mills, a suburb of Fort Lauderdale where many factory outlets have opened. Ask your hotel concierge how to get there—you'll probably need a car.

Sawgrass Mills
12801 W Sunrise Blvd
Sunrise, FL 33323

+1 305 954 2350

www.simon.com/mall/sawgrass-mills

content.title: Miami Beach: a superb ensemble of Art Deco buildings

introduction.small: In this one-of-a-kind neighbourhood, there are hundreds of beautifully restored Art Deco buildings.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Miami Beach: a superb ensemble of Art Deco buildings

paragraphs.text:
Thanks to the Miami Design Preservation League, a heritage protection society, as well as tax aid, this neighbourhood was not only preserved but also restored in 1976. Built between 1925 and 1930 in the Art Deco style, these buildings had become very dilapidated.

In 1980, the facades were painted in pastel colours, which was not the case originally. The result is a magnificent architectural ensemble almost 800 buildings just in front of the ocean. You will find the most remarkable buildings along Ocean Drive between 6th and 23rd Street: Park Central Hotel, the Colony Hotel, the Waldorf Towers Hotel, the Breakwater Hotel, Edison Hotel and the Hotel Victor.

Do not just admire the facades at night, neon lights add extra colour. Go into the lobbies to see the mouldings, chandeliers, and tiled floors.

Miami Design Preservation League
1001 Ocean Drive
Miami Beach, FL 33139

+1 305 672 2014

www.mdpl.org

content.title: Fontainebleau: a landmark hotel

introduction.small: Opened in the 1950s, the Fontainebleau is a Miami Beach institution: a huge ship built in front of the beach.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fontainebleau: a landmark hotel

paragraphs.text:
Here's a movie trivia question for you. In the first scenes of Goldfinger, a James Bond movie shot in 1964, a murdered woman covered in gold paint is discovered in a hotel room. Where were these scenes shot? Why, at the Fontainebleau, this huge, iconic, five-star hotel in Miami…

Opened in 1954, the Fontainebleau was where Frank Sinatra and Elvis Presley performed. It was renovated in 2008, and the facelift, which cost a billion dollars, did it a great deal of good. It has even been expanded: there are 1,504 nicely furnished suites with sea views and balconies.

Don't be put off by the lobby, with its marble columns and chandeliers: the staff is efficient and competent. And, the pool, even though its Hollywood decor is gone, is immense.

Fontainebleau Miami Beach
4441 Collins Avenue
Miami Beach, FL 33140

+1 305 538 2000

www.fontainebleau.com

Rooms: from 299 USD

content.title: The Setai: Asian-influenced luxury

introduction.small: Discreet elegance reigns in this hotel, where the decor and ambience are inspired by Asia.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Setai: Asian-influenced luxury

paragraphs.text:
The Setai, a legendary Art Deco hotel, reopened its doors in 2013, entirely renovated. Far from the ostentatious decoration of many Miami Beach institutions, it still has the Oriental serenity that makes it so unique, along with three swimming pools and four restaurants.

The Burmese teak panels in the lobby are hand-made. The understated elegance that reigns in this hotel is particularly visible in the 120 rooms and suites, particularly the spacious Art Deco suites of this historic 1930s building. They are beautifully decorated with works of Asian-inspired art. With the greatest of care, the graceful coming-and-going of the staff is orchestrated by Chef concierge Maïté Foriasky. In the kitchen of the Jaya restaurant, veteran chef Vijayudu Veena tastefully blends spices. A great opportunity to enjoy and an excellent introduction to Silk Road cuisine.

The Setai
2001 Collins Avenue
Miami Beach, FL 33139

+1 888 625 7500

https://www.thesetaihotels.com/en-us/hotels/miami-beach

Rooms: from 653 USD

content.title: The Everglades: nature in the raw

introduction.small: You have never seen so many alligators, which can be a real thrill!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Everglades: nature in the raw

paragraphs.text:
Alligators, manatees, pelicans, raccoons, and flamingos all these animals live in the Everglades National Park, the third largest in the United States. Visiting this park is easy: rent a car in Miami, take Tamiami Trail, and then Highway 41.

Once in this immense sub-tropical swamp, overgrown with mangroves, you can take a tour in an airboat, those noisy flat-bottomed boats with airplane propellers, which slide over the water just like they do over grass. This is a good way to see a lot of wildlife, even if you have to cover your ears because of the racket.

There are alligators everywhere; you can see them while walking or biking around. They never come up to you. But though these charming little beasts look perfectly placid, they always sleep with one eye open. Tip: bring powerful mosquito repellent.

Shark Valley Visitor Center
36000 SW 8th St
Miami, FL 33194

+1 305 221 8776

www.nps.gov

content.title: Bayside Marketplace: lively shopping

introduction.small: Visit this gigantic mall before embarking on a cruise around the islands, inhabited by famous artists and the rich.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bayside Marketplace: lively shopping

paragraphs.text:
Close to 150 stores, bars, and restaurants-like the Hard Rock Café-covering more than eight hectares await tourists here. Put like that, you may not want to go, and yet it is always crowded. Certainly, the complex, close to the port, attracts cruise passengers, especially those who find the huge mall appealing, but there are quietly strolling families as well, and young people window-shopping, and tourists on shopping trips.

There are free concerts in the late afternoon. If you look out to sea, you can admire the enormous cruise ships-impressive white monsters-that carry up to 6,000 passengers.

From the Bayside Marketplace, you can embark on a more modest 1 ½-hour mini-cruise. The boat navigates around islands where billionaires live in sumptuous villas surrounded by immaculate gardens. And it is always fun to hear the guide say how much they paid for them…

Bayside Marketplace
401 Biscayne Blvd
Miami, FL 33132

+1 305 577 3344

www.baysidemarketplace.com

content.title: MOCA : nothing but contemporary art

introduction.small: In the north of Miami, the Museum of Contemporary Art wants to make art accessible to all.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: MOCA : nothing but contemporary art

paragraphs.text:
Hidden behind Little Haiti, MOCA is far from the trendy neighbourhoods. Though it is small in size, the MOCA is a giant in its ability to spot talent: the museum owns about 600 works.

Opened in 1996, in a building designed by a New York architect, it is interesting in more ways than one. Its priority is to make contemporary art accessible to all, especially lower-income people. Moreover, it gives great prominence to emerging artists. MOCA is known for its innovative, even provocative exhibitions, of which there are between eight and ten every year. This does not prevent it from also putting together mainstream exhibitions.

In recent years, it has shown exhibitions of world-famous artists like Julian Schnabel, Dan Flavin, Louise Bourgeois, and Annette Messager. On the last Friday of each month, a jazz concert is scheduled. There is no admission fee for visiting the garden.

Museum of Contemporary Art (MOCA)
770 NE 125th St
Miami, FL 33161

+1 305 893 6211

www.mocanomi.org

content.title: Zuma: the top Miami restaurant

introduction.small: Despite the high prices, this is one of the hardest reservations to get in all of Miami.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Zuma: the top Miami restaurant

paragraphs.text:
This restaurant is one of the best in the city. Since it first opened in London in 2002, others Zumas have popped up, and there are now ten worldwide.

Here, as elsewhere, the room is extremely elegant, with pale green armchairs in which you are served delicious and extremely original Japanese cuisine. Two of the chef's signature dishes are the gindara no saikyo miso yaki, (marinated cod), and the karami in zuke sauce (a tender piece of spicy beef topped with sesame seeds, red hot pepper and sweet soy sauce). The brunch comes with unlimited Champagne. The only downside is the noise.

Ask to be seated on the lovely terrace by the river. And make sure you're well dressed-otherwise, you won't get a seat anywhere.

Zuma
270 Biscayne Blvd Way
Miami, FL 33131

+1 305 577 0277

www.zumarestaurant.com

Menu: from 70 USD

content.title: Smith and Wollensky: the meat specialist

introduction.small: People come to this restaurant for its hearty dishes and elegant ambiance.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Smith and Wollensky: the meat specialist

paragraphs.text:
The success of this restaurant, a classic and excellent steakhouse, is undeniable. If you have been to one of the chain's establishments in New York, Chicago, or Washington you know the formula.

Here, across from the entrance to the channel, in this colonial house, the atmosphere is very elegant. The tables in this large bright room with sea view are well spaced, with white tablecloths, and comfortable chairs. If you're famished, rest assured: the plates are large. The specialty of the menu is of course, meat, especially filet mignon, beef tartare, and sirloin steaks.

But you may prefer the truffle mac & cheese, barbecued tuna served with seaweed salad or the generous seafood platter. The desserts are homemade, and the wine list is remarkable. At night, ask to dine on the terrace overlooking the bay, where a romantic atmosphere is guaranteed.

Smith and Wollensky
1 Washington Avenue
Miami Beach, FL 33139

+1 305 673 2800

www.smithandwollensky.com

Menu: from 70 USD

content.title: Long bike rides

introduction.small: Miami's flat topography and numerous cycle paths make it a perfect biking city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Long bike rides

paragraphs.text:
Cycling is a good way to travel in Miami and its surroundings, as there are many cycling paths to choose from. In addition, the sunny climate lends itself to pleasant bike journeys. Several routes are available to you, depending on your endurance and the time you have available.

Start by exploring the Art Deco district of Miami Beach: from the south of the city, go along the waterfront, turn onto Washington Avenue, take Lincoln Avenue and do some shopping or have a coffee. After, go along Meridian Avenue, which takes you back to the southern tip of Miami Beach. Another possibility, for the more intrepid: start at Lincoln Road and get onto the Venetian Causeway by crossing the islands before arriving in downtown Miami. For the most motivated, the path that leads to Virginia Key and Key Biscayne via Rickenbacker is very nice.

If you get tired, Metrorail accepts bikes. Several companies rent bicycles, but there is also a self-service bike system (modelled on Paris' Vélib' programme).

Bike & Roll Miami
210 10th St
Miami, FL 33139

+1 305 604 0001

www.bikemiami.com

content.title: The Wolfsonian Museum: for design connoisseurs

introduction.small: With its collections of objects of all kinds, this museum is entirely dedicated to design. Fun and informative.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Wolfsonian Museum: for design connoisseurs

paragraphs.text:
Opened in 1995, The Wolfsonian Museum, housed in an imposing seven-storey building of Moorish style built in 1927, is the temple of design. It brings together thousands of objects in eclectic collections that entertain young and old.

Do not miss the magnificent collection patiently put together by philanthropist and art lover Mitchell Wolfson, Jr. on the 5th level. It consists of American and European objects from the 19th and 20th centuries. In total, there are about 300 pieces, some of which are considered emblematic, like the gold-leaf lacquered wood pieces designed by Jean Dunand during the Art Deco period.

Paintings, photos, sculptures, and books, as well as everyday items, are also well represented. As Wolfson once said: ‘The objects made by men and women tell us about human behaviour much better than any other form of expression.' In 1997, he bequeathed his collection to the University of Florida.

Wolfsonian Museum
1001 Washington Avenue
Miami Beach, FL 33139

+1 305 531 1001

www.wolfsonian.org

content.title: New World Center: the architect's symphony

introduction.small: In this superb building by talented architect Frank Gehry, the music is sublime.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: New World Center: the architect's symphony

paragraphs.text:
Architect of the new Louis Vuitton Foundation in Paris and the Guggenheim Bilbao, Frank Gehry designed this monument in a park known as the Miami Beach Soundscape. It took nearly three years and $160 million before this building was finished in January 2011.

From the outside, one sees only its huge glass facade, which gives the atrium beautiful light throughout the day. Inside, there are the curves and volumes that are the hallmark of Gehry. For spectators, there are 756 seats, none of which are more than 13 rows from the stage. The acoustics are reportedly excellent.

This achievement illustrates how Miami Beach is attracting the stars of world architecture: next door, in Lincoln Road, Swiss duo Herzog & de Meuron have designed a building. Guided tours of the New World Center are by booking.

New World Center
500 17th St
Miami Beach FL 33139

+1 305 673 3330

www.nws.edu

content.title: Discover downtown Miami

introduction.small: The Metromover has become a tourist attraction. It's a pleasant way to visit the city centre. And it's free.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover downtown Miami

paragraphs.text:
With three lines, the small blue-and-white Metromover travels from the northern district of downtown Miami to the south. Elevated, driverless, fast, and, above all, free, it is useful to all both for people getting to work as well as for tourists who find it an original and undemanding way to discover the city. You will see some nice neighbourhoods and some that are disadvantaged.

If you want to take pictures of the buildings, you've got to stand right in front of them. As the metro is free, don't hesitate to get off and walk from one station to the next.

Get off at the Tenth Street/Promenade station in the south and take a walk in the business district. Look at the beautiful houses along Brickell Avenue. The Bay front Park Station is bucolic. Get off there and walk through a pretty, shady green space. At Government Center, several museums await you. The Metromover runs from 5:00 a.m. until midnight.

+1 305 891 3131

https://www8.miamidade.gov/global/transportation/metromover.page

content.title: Little Havana: the Cuban neighbourhood

introduction.small: This is the first area Cuban immigrants came to in Miami, and it's where they have kept their traditions. Before, perhaps, returning home one day...

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Little Havana: the Cuban neighbourhood

paragraphs.text:
The heart of Cuban Miami is in a neighbourhood called “Little Havana”. This area, around 8th Street, “Calle Ocho”, is where the first immigrants fleeing the Castro regime settled down. Admire the folk-art frescoes illustrating the street's walls.

To really put yourself in a Cuban mood, buy a traditional shirt in white linen, the guayabera, which is ideal for hot weather. The weekend is when the neighbourhood really comes alive. Imitate Cubans sipping espressos, ahem, “cafes cubanos”, in small paper cups, and taste delicious cakes drowning in sugar.

Several good restaurants on Calle Ocho offer traditional cuisine, especially the best known, Versailles. Do not miss the Brigade 2506 Memorial: erected in homage to the several hundred Cubans who went back to try to overthrow Fidel Castro in 1961, this monument still arouses emotion, as many were killed, while others were imprisoned.

Restaurant Versailles
3555 SW 8th St
Miami, FL 33135

+1 305 444 0240

www.versaillesrestaurant.com

content.title: The Standard Spa: a hotel on an island

introduction.small: This four-star hotel is famous for its huge pool and spa—ideal recovery areas after sightseeing in the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Standard Spa: a hotel on an island

paragraphs.text:
Far from most hotels in Miami Beach, this hotel enjoys an exceptional location on the island of Belle Isle in Biscayne Bay. With its modern and comfortable rooms, it offers simple accommodation in a warm atmosphere that attracts a younger clientele.

The rain showers in the bathrooms are great, but customers are most captivated by the hotel's spa and wellness area. The treatments are based on traditional practices from around the world, especially Russia and Turkey. Experienced trainers offer effective fitness programs, and there are also excellent Yoga teachers on staff.

The sauna, steam bath, and the huge pool facing the sea, one of the biggest in Miami, also contribute to the hotel's reputation. The Bayside restaurant is a nice dinner spot, with superb sunsets on view.

The Standard Spa
40 Island Avenue
Miami Beach, FL 33139

+1 305 673 1717

www.standardhotels.com/miami/spa

Rooms: from 199 USD

content.title: Pubbelly: Asian and American influences

introduction.small: This Miami Beach restaurant's success is due to fair prices, delicious cuisine, and excellent service.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pubbelly: Asian and American influences

paragraphs.text:
When he lived with his parents in Puerto Rico, Jose Mendin's mother did all the cooking. Since moving out, he has learned how to cook for himself. And he does it very well. After working in various restaurants, and taking several internships, particularly in Spain, he created Pubbelly, with associates, in 2010. This was followed by Pubbelly Sushi the following year.

In this district under renovation best to work out your itinerary before you head out-he combines Asian and American influences. His proposals are often very original and delicious. Try the tuna tartare in wasabi cream, shrimp tempura or yakitori-style chicken with ginger, miso and sesame seeds, and you will be conquered. Very good desserts complement the main courses.

Add a friendly atmosphere, attentive service, and reasonable prices, and you'll understand why the restaurant is so successful. Indeed, numerous gastronomic prizes have been awarded to this talented chef.

Pubbelly
1418 20th St
Miami Beach, FL 33139

+1 305 532 7555

www.pubbelly.com

Menu: from 50 USD

content.title: Sagamore: a hotel that will make you love art

introduction.small: This was one of the first hotels to hang artwork everywhere, a decision made by its owners, who are amateur painters.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sagamore: a hotel that will make you love art

paragraphs.text:
To stay here, you had better love art. Because the owners of the Sagamore, the Taplins, are art addicts. So much so that when they opened the hotel in 2001, they wanted to share the collection they had begun years earlier with their guests and anyone curious who happened to wander into the lobby. They even commissioned works directly from artists. In the dining room, stairs, and, of course, in the bedrooms are different works from their collection, which includes photos, paintings, poolside sculptures, and videos in the garden.

In total, more than 400 pieces are scattered throughout the hotel. The 93 suites—with living room and kitchen–are perfect for a couple with a child.

They are very comfortable and large, none smaller than 42 square meters. Built in 1948, the building, with its refined volumes, is a post-Art Deco architectural icon.

Sagamore
1671 Collins Avenue
Miami Beach, FL 33139

+1 305 535 8088

www.sagamorehotel.com

Rooms: from 219 USD

content.title: Joe's Stone Crab, the crab-claw king

introduction.small: This is one of the most famous restaurants in Miami Beach. Come taste the specialty that has made its reputation for decades.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Joe's Stone Crab, the crab-claw king

paragraphs.text:
This is a South Beach institution. The house specialty: crab claws accompanied by delicious sauce, but only served from October to May. Equally tasty is the Key lime pie.

The restaurant opened in the early 1920s when Joe, who suffered from asthma, and Jennie Weiss, both of Hungarian origin, left New York. At the time, good food was scarce in this part of Miami Beach. They opened a small spot and it was a success, and it has never wavered since. The restaurant is still in the family, generations later. Local customers and tourists throng to it. No reservations: you give your name when you arrive, have a drink at the bar, and wait for them to call you when a table becomes free.

First come, first served, so it is best to arrive early. If you don't want to wait, they do takeaway.

Joe's Stone Crab
11 Washington Avenue
Miami Beach, FL 33139

+1 305 673 0365

www.facebook.com/JoesStoneCrab

Menu: from 65 USD

content.title: Le Bouchon du Grove: the cuisine of Lyon in Miami

introduction.small: Foie gras, chicken fricassee, and beef bourguignon are all specialties of a chef straight from France.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Bouchon du Grove: the cuisine of Lyon in Miami

paragraphs.text:
Here's a little piece of France right in Coconut Grove, the former Bahamian immigrant district that is today a fashionable residential area.

Chef Christian Ville arrived in Miami in 1998, after having trained with French greats Troisgros and Bocuse. The decor of this small restaurant evokes the great bouchons of Lyon, with red-and-white checked table settings. The menu offers typical French dishes: gratinée lyonnaise, snails, beef bourguignon, foie gras, and filet mignon. One of the house specialities, duck legs in confit served with roasted potatoes cooked in duck fat and a cep mushroom sauce, available for dinner, is exquisite.

If you're still hungry, try a tarte Tatin or a crème brûlée. With a little imagination, you just might believe you're in France.

Le Bouchon du Grove
3430 Main Highway
Miami, FL 33133

+1 305 448 6060

www.lebouchondugrove.com

Menu: from 40 USD

content.title: Delano: a gem by Philippe Starck

introduction.small: White, white, and more white. The Delano is a design hotel whose success is undeniable.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Delano: a gem by Philippe Starck

paragraphs.text:
What best characterises the Delano hotel is probably its colour: pure white. This was what French designer Philippe Starck, who renovated the hotel in 1995, wanted and it has contributed to the revival of Miami Beach. Opened in 1947 and named after the 32nd president of the United States, Franklin Delano Roosevelt, this hotel has newfound youthfulness. White fabrics flutter in the lobby, giving a refreshing impression. There are just a few chairs and armchairs, so as not to disturb the feeling of serenity. The 194 rooms, of course, are all white, occasionally enlivened by grey or pale green. On weekends, an excellent brunch with Champagne and lobster is served. You will enjoy the large swimming pool surrounded by palm trees and blue-and-white-striped deck chairs. On Sundays, it is open to anyone with a few dollars, so expect pretty girls and tanned and muscular young men parading noisily. If you like the quiet, then avoid the noise by going to the beach. Accessible at the end of the garden, it will welcome you.

Delano
1685 Collins Avenue
Miami Beach, FL 33139

+1 305 672 2000

www.delano-hotel.com

Rooms: from 280 USD

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Miami
content.introduction: Miami has a subtropical climate. Summers are hot and humid, with occasional thunderstorms from May to October. This period coincides with hurricane season. Among US cities, Miami has one of the highest average relative humidity levels, but it is also one of the sunniest. Temperatures often exceed 30°C (86°F). Winters are mild and dry. At this time of the year, temperatures range from 15°C (59°F) at night to 25°C (77°F) during the day.

content.title: Currency and Exchange Rates
content.description: The currency used in the United States of America is the dollar ($).
content.validity: The above exchange rate is given for information because is variable.

airports.title: Miami International Airport
airports.description:
Miami International Airport is located approximately 11 kilometres (7 miles) from the city centre.
  • 3 terminals:
    • North Terminal
    • Central Terminal
    • South Terminal (Air France)
  • Miami International Airport is located approximately 11 kilometres (7 miles) from the city centre.
    • 3 terminals:
      • North Terminal
      • Central Terminal
      • South Terminal (Air France)

    Getting from the airport to Miami and back:
    • By car
      • Accessible via NW 72nd Avenue.
      • For parking, the Dolphin (North) Garage serves the North Terminal and the Flamingo (South) Garage serves the Central Terminal. USD 2 for 20 minutes, USD 17 for 24 hours.
      • Several car rental companies have counters at the Rental Car Center (RCC) in Central Station.
      • There are a number of other car rental companies that do not have counters at the RCC but have agencies located not far from the airport.
    • By rail
      • The Metrorail's Orange Line is the most convenient and affordable option to get to and from the city centre. The standard fare is USD 2.25.
    • By taxi
      • Taxis are available on the arrivals level, outside the baggage claim areas. The fare to central Miami is about USD 22.
    • By shuttle
      • SuperShuttle offers van services on the arrivals level, outside the baggage claim areas. The fare to central Miami is about USD 14.
    • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
    • Telephone: +1 305 876 7000
    • Website: : www.miami-airport.com

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Miami
transportation.description: Miami is quite a large city, but its public transport system offers extensive coverage of the entire area.

touristInformation.title: Visitor information
touristInformation.description: Upon your arrival in Miami, you can get in touch with local tourism professionals for further information and to help organize your stay.

information.title: Greater Miami Convention & Visitor's Bureau
information.description:
Offers practical information and many useful recommendations (accommodation, restaurants, public transport, festivals, cultural events, etc.).

  • Address: 701 Brickell Ave. Suite 2700 - Miami, FL 33131
  • Telephone: +1 305 539 3000
  • Website: http://www.miamiandbeaches.com

information.title: Further information available online for visitors to the United States
information.description:
Discover America, a public-private marketing entity, works closely with the travel industry to promote tourism in communities around the country. Its website offers excellent information on all US travel destinations, including Miami and South Florida.

  • Website: www.office-tourisme-usa.com

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description: See your doctor before you travel. It is also recommended to take out insurance covering medical expenses and repatriation before your trip. Miami counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

information.title: Vaccinations
information.description:
There are no vaccination requirements for visitors to the United States.

For more information, contact Air France's international vaccination centre:

  • Address: 38, Quai de Jemmapes, 75010 Paris
  • Website: www.vaccinations-airfrance.fr
  • Telephone: +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00
  • To make a vaccination appointment:
    • online (click here)
    • call the centre at +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00

information.title: Water
information.description: Tap water is safe to drink in Miami.

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Miami

events.title: Third Monday in January : Martin Luther King Day (national holiday)
events.description: A federal holiday in the United States, celebrating the life and achievements of Martin Luther King, Jr. In recent years, it has increasingly been seen as a day of service, when Americans are encouraged to volunteer to help others less fortunate than themselves. It is also celebrated with a colourful parade including musicians and dancers in the streets of Miami.

events.title: January/February : Chinese New Year (local)
events.description: Miami rings in the Chinese New Year with large parades, dances, tai chi demonstrations, traditional music, food and entertainment.

events.title: July 4 : Independence Day (national holiday)
events.description: A federal holiday in the United States commemorating the adoption of the Declaration of Independence on July 4, 1776. Celebrated with parades, military marches and fireworks.

events.title: 31 octobre
events.description: Halloween is celebrated each year by Americans of all ages. In the late afternoon and early evening hours, children don costumes and go door-to-door in their neighbourhoods to ask for treats, typically candy.

events.title: Fourth Thursday in November : Thanksgiving (national holiday)
events.description: Originally a Christian religious observance, for many years Thanksgiving has been a secular holiday in the United States, celebrated by Americans of all faiths. Families come together to prepare and enjoy a large feast at home. The meal typically includes roast turkey with stuffing, mashed potatoes, cranberry sauce as well as various side dishes and ends with an assortment of pies (pumpkin, pecan, apple).

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for the United States
administrativeProcedures.description:
The Visa Waiver Program (VWP) allows citizens of participating countries to travel to the United States without a visa for stays of 90 days or less, whether for tourism or business. Two requirements must be met:

  • Your passport must meet the criteria for VWP travel (it must be machine-readable, with an integrated chip containing information from the passport data page). For further information, visit the Visa Waiver Program page on the Website of the Bureau of Consular Affairs, U.S. Department of State: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/us-visas/tourism-visit/visa-waiver-program.html

You must have a valid Electronic System for Travel Authorization (ESTA) prior to travel. For further information, visit the ESTA page on the U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Website: https://www.cbp.gov/travel/international-visitors/esta

Travellers not eligible for the VWP, or who have not been able to obtain an ESTA, must apply for a visa.

To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Miami and the United States, be sure to check with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in your home country for the latest travel information and recommendations. Comprehensive information that may be helpful is also provided on the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs’ website:

View information for travellers to the United States

goodToKnow.title: Good to know

administration.title: Government offices
administration.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. and 2:30 p.m. to 5 p.m.

banks.title: Banks
banks.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. and Saturday from 9 a.m. to noon

goodToKnow.daylightSavingTime:
Start of daylight saving time: second Sunday in March
End of daylight saving time: first Sunday in November
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
In Miami as in the rest of the United States, a service charge is not included in the bill and tips form a major portion of income for waiting staff. Prices on restaurant menus are indicated before taxes and tips. You are therefore expected to leave a tip (generally between 15 and 20 percent of the bill). Tipping less than 15 percent (or leaving no tip at all) means that you are very dissatisfied with the service.
